comments.commentBody: Haha sorry teetotalers, the potheads have you on the mat, the ref is counting.
yawwwwwwwwwwnnnn
Mr. Viera I really think that you and the other NYT writers buried the lede tonight - a dominating pitching performance by a 21 year old rookie backed by some exceptional defense.
World Cup: who won?  Who knows?  I remember the octopus Paul.

Sandomir says: "But it's not history. He wasn't the youngest."

If wasn't the youngest, he won't go into the record books as the youngest, and nothing will change that. Whether he made history we don't know. That could be a more complicated question than whether he was youngest. Some of it we could figure out soon from analyzing more historical statistics. Some of it we will have to wait until more history plays itself out.

Why object to Sandomir's observation? The broadcast media criticism is deserved, okay. Yet some observations or evaluations of your own would be better than just picking apart what the broadcasters say. Unless you fear being picked apart yourself.
Very nice.  My first one of these. Over 8/13ths, what a hoot!

As an undergraduate Philosophy major at NYU many years ago, I can say that Philosophy Professors were the teachers most likely to truly listen to what students would say. Of course the risk was that the response could be stunningly blunt. I remember making a point which was answered by, "So what?", and quickly realized that I had better HAVE a point before I opened my mouth! But I WAS being taken seriously.

I also remember the plight of an air "de-ionizing" device salesman who did not realize that he had been invited to pitch his device to a room fool of PhDs who had problems with the departments air quality. He might as well have presented a case befor the Supreme Court!

Those were the days when you could smoke a cigarette with your Professor during office hours discussing Saul Kripke. Those days are gone!

I found your article an excellent piece, highly informative and extremely readable!

I find your phrase 'Philosophers are a garrulous and argumentative species' to be definative and to my sense accurate.

Pray give me a boon to answer two questions.

1. On Philsosophy: What is your simplest definition of Philosophy?

2. On Photography and Truth: any professional Photographer can make the subject appear any way that photographer wishes. During my life I have play about with cameras and have caught a subject in a blink which made the subject look drunk which was not the case, so photographs can lie.

My second question is: Does the Sun rise in the East and set in the West? Is this statement True or false.

I am not a philosper I am just a plain Homo sapiens sapiens and none of the people of my type are inferior to me.

Happy Halloe'en

firstthought

Re: 551. truth Karachi 10:59 am

“It is amazing that Al-Qaeda, a 'handful' and ragtag, scattered bunch can make 300 million most well-equipped Americans, shiver in their boots. Looks like David and Goliath. But aren't there any people in the great US think tanks that can discover the way to end this perpetual confrontation? “

---

The problem is think tanks can’t think outside the box… uh,… tank.

The "think" tanks are beholden to the Washington Establishment.

And Sacred Cows cannot be gored.
We always find these things after the fact even though we spend $80 Billion per year in intelligence services. Is it time for a new thinking?

It is time for this world to come together to stop these attacks by establishing a lunar penal colony just for these terrorists that apparently do not want to live on Earth and would prefer to make everyone miserable by their actions.  We should start to view ourselves as citizens of Earth and these people that commit such acts as aliens that deserve to be off of this planet.

YES YES YES to comment 149.
I would be happy and pleased to trade--the sarcastic comments reflected here for my grief and loss from the
events of September 11--
I fear that "you all" do not know of what you "speak"--
You need only one Frankestein. Osama in Laden, the one haunting the world. He was created to serve a purpose and once it was done, the creator could not take care of him. Sheer tragedy.

Time to take all cargo other than passenger luggage and maybe mail in small envelopes only aboard passenger flights.
Its also time to get rid of this upside down airline logic that charges passengers extra to check luggage their first one or two pieces of luggage. Banning carry-on baggage would not only make the passenger compartments safer but it would dramatically speed up boarding and leaving planes. With current practices and fee schedules safety and security are taking a big, back seat to airline profits. Ridiculous!!

Many of those interviewed for this article protest that no one ever complains to them, so obviously they don't smell. They seem to feel this is the only logical conclusion. Has it ever occurred to them that their colleagues and friends are too embarrassed to tell them that they reek? That the comments are all behind their backs and out of their hearing? Most people are too embarrassed to tell a friend that they are offensively aromatic. I know I am. They should be aware that they are most likely inured to their own odors, since most people tend to become insensitive to smells that are omnipresent - hence the fact that most smokers seem to be blissfully unaware that their hair, skin and breath is deadly. I'll bet a lot of these jokers also sniff and then re-wear their clothes "one more time" before laundering them. I have encountered many of these folks on elevators, mass transit and elsewhere. Does anyone remember the old Madison Avenue mouthwash commercial - "Your best friend won't tell you"? Well, you unwashed, undeodorized folk out there, let ME tell you - you DO smell bad.

People that acually smell probably smell regardless of using deodorant.

I stopped using deodorant when I started college in Seattle. I'd grown up in a much hotter state, where I did sweat. And then, in Seattle, it wasn't hot at all, so I wasn't sweating. Realized it was pointless to use deodorant and have barely used it since.

If your body is generating a lot of body odor, it's probably diet-related or some other cause, not just because you don't shower daily. And I'd be willing to bet that some people whom others think they stink actually do shower daily 'n' such.

I was surprised not to see this mentioned in the article, nor appearing on the numerous comments here.  Surely, I can't be the only one who put 2 & 2 together to end up with rubbing alcohol as a deodorant.  It's my recollection (from an NYT Science section piece) that bacteria mixing with our underarm secretions was the cause of odor.  Remove the bacteria - remove the odor.  It's worked very well for me for decades.

this article is news? i don't shower every day, haven't for years. i shower around 2-3x/week. i do use deodorant every day, though, just because i do like to be on the safe side. on a few occasions i have asked close friends and family, who i know are honest with me, to tell me if i smell, and everyone has always said - "no, you're fine!"

for me, the benefits - beyond the fact that clearly, i don't NEED to be showering more than i am, for any sort of "smell" reasons, are - 1) i have curly hair and it does MUCH better with less washing; and 2) unexpected - i constantly get compliments on my skin. and questions like - "what do you use?" to which i have to say, nothing, really. it's what i DON'T use that makes it glow. our bodies produce natural oils that are far better for our skin than any manufactured lotion.
I am really on board with this philosophy.  The trick, and the reason that there is no point in being anti it, is to be flexible and respond to your body's needs.

Oh to be so lucky as all these commentators! At the end of the day my hair is greasy and I smell. Even if I don't work out. Apparently I am not as lucky as everyone else seems to be. Yes - my skin gets dry, but without a daily shower my hair is a greasy mess (it's very fine) and my bod feels dirty. P.S. I LOVE antiperspirant!

As a Dermatologist for more than 20 years in the tristate area, I am certainly in agreement that us Americans are just too clean. Case in point: one of the most common patient complaints in a Dermatologist's office is itch. The most common cause of itch is probably dry skin from overshowering.  My patients are amazed when I tell them to put down the scrub brushes, loofah sponges and wash clothes and suggest a five minute shower using a bar of Dove or other gentle soap. I do not advocate the avoidance of deodorant. I simply say to wash the groin, armpits, face, shampoo the hair and get out of the shower. There is no need to soap and scrub the arms or legs every day or to allow the hot water to sit on one's back for twenty minutes.  Allowing the natural oils to remain on the skin is certainly more effective than any moisturizer. So maybe cleanliness is not next to Godliness.

Some comments prompt me to ask these questions: How can you tell if someone bathes three times a week or never bathes? When you meet, or stand next to a smelly stranger, are you just assuming that he smells like that because he has gone two days without a bath? You have never heard of people who rarely take a bath? Are the only alternatives for everybody to either take a shower everyday or be dirty beyond belief?

And unfortunately there are some people who smell even if they bathe everyday...

I only wash my hair once or twice a week, and I've been doing this for years. I think the trend to shower daily came about because of advertising--shampoo and soap companies wanting to move more product. Plus, what a huge waste of water! Now we need to start getting rid of unnecessary consumer products as well--Dixie cups and dryer sheets should be the first to go...

My favorite game to play on the subway is "Who Smells?" whereby I try to sniff out the person who is giving off an offending odor. Game to me if I can narrow it down to the single stinky person. It never gets old and I never run out of players.

A dermatologist once told me that we don't need to use soap everyday, because it does dry the skin. He suggested that every other day I just rinse in water, and that, not too hot. So that's what I do. I was also told by my GYN that certain soaps are too harsh for those certain parts, and that water is best, followed by mild, fragrance-free soaps (Cetaphil, for example). Sometimes I'll rinse twice a day, depending on the weather and my activity. Showers don't have to be long, you can have a good rinse in 3 minutes or less and still come out fresh and clean. As far as I'm concerned, everyone should wear at least a deodorant, if not a full antiperspirant, at least in NYC!

The only time I don't bathe is when I know I'm going to be in my own company and environment for that day.

I think there's a huge natural variation in how stinky different people can get. My boyfriend could probably run a marathon and not need any de-scenting afterward but I had a roommate in college who smelled pretty ripe after just a few hours of sitting around word processing. All these people whining about the unbearably fragrant NYC subway should really spend a little time on public transit in Moscow, Bombay, Dakar. Smelling like you work for a living is just not the most embarrassing or shameful state of affairs that there is in the world.
